result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.
result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Tanner Joseph Sturgul

records.addlTxt:
2:51 PM Defendant Tanner Joseph Sturgul in court, in custody. Attorney Mitchell Reagan LaCombe in court for Tanner Joseph Sturgul.  Prosecuting attorney Claudia T. Johnson in court for the State of Wisconsin. 
Court received waiver to extradition signed by all parties.
Extradition hearing on October 19, 2022 at 02:00 pm.

03:34 PM Defendant Tanner Joseph Sturgul appeared by phone, in custody.  Attorney Mitchell Reagan LaCombe in court for Tanner Joseph Sturgul.  Attorney Joel Urmanski appeared by phone for State of Wisconsin. Def wants to waive extradition back to the State of Illinois. Def agrees he is the person in the complaint. State will prepare the paperwork for extradition, but the hearing must be in person to witness the signing of the paperwork.
Extradition hearing scheduled for October 19, 2022 at 02:00 pm.
To Court from Defendant RE: Waiving of Extradition Hearing
